clean_story:
Focused moments. Fleeting concentration.

"Attention" describes how long we can lock onto a task before our minds wander—like a flashlight beam that dims or shifts after 8–12 seconds.


We assume attention is steady, but it’s more like a flickering candle.
Studies show the brain’s "attention network" tires quickly, forcing micro-breaks every 20 minutes—even if we don’t notice.
Try reading a page without re-reading lines: your eyes jump back 15% of the time, a glitch called regression.


Multitasking? A myth.
Switching tasks costs 23 minutes of focus per interruption, per UC Irvine research.
A chef chopping veggies while stirring sauce isn’t multitasking—it’s habit stacking, two actions fused by repetition.


The limits aren’t just mental.
Your pupils dilate when concentrating, shrinking when distracted—like a camera lens adjusting.
Even your heartbeat slows by 1–2 BPM during deep focus, a quirk called attentional bradycardia.


Push past 90 minutes, and errors spike 50%—the brain’s "ultradian rhythm" demands rest.
Yet pilots land planes after 10-hour shifts, surgeons operate for 14.
Their secret? Chunking—breaking tasks into 7-minute bursts with micro-goals.


Flow states. Cognitive load. The Pomodoro Technique’s 25-minute sprints.
